text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - then there’s no question that hormone therapy will cause more side effects than radiation. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: There’s no question about that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, if your goal is to try to eradicate as much of the cancer as fast as possible – Family Member: Um hum. DOC - then the best way to do that although it’s still not a cure is hormone therapy plus or minus something else. So something new. Doctor: Right, so there’s no question that hormone therapy within the first three months is going to kill like ninety-nine percent of the cancer. Happens with almost everyone. With radiotherapy you know there’s a decent chance that it’s going to kill whatever cancer happens to be part that we radiate – Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: - but the rest of the cancer which is going to be invisible is obviously going to be outside of that radiation field. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: It’s not going to be touched. And the concern with that is although I am a proponent of someone that wants to – If your goal is absolutely to avoid hormone therapy as long as possible, that’s a good option for you. And again, what would be driving that would be more quality of life.

text: Patient: I think, I think you answered all my questions pretty good. Huh, the only thing, the chemo. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: When would that start? Doctor: Huh, so, it, that would start if you are doing the clinical trial, then once you sign the paper, you could start a couple of days after that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so it’s not going to delay getting that started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I still would want at least one or two weeks off of the abiraterone before I would get started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if you, you know, end up telling me, you know, this doesn’t make sense for me. Patient: No. I’m good with the morphine.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a clinical trial where we’re giving the chemotherapy and everybody gets an infusion two to three times a week. So- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: for someone coming from F___ may it may be too much to come in here that often, but we’re giving Vitamin C to half the people and half the people don’t because some data says that Vitamin C may reduce the side effects of the chemotherapy and also help the benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But we don’t know that. It could be just folly; it could be the truth- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And so half the people get it, half the people don’t- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but you still have to come in and get an infusion three times a week. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so that one is logistically pretty tough. But that is something that you know if we’re going chemotherapy, I can make sure we get you the permission slip or the consent form to let you know what that would look like.

text: Patient: So, that’s your immune system. Doctor: That’s the immune system. Patient: So, what happens in between, does that weaken your immune system or? Doctor: No, it actually if anything strengthens. Patient: I mean while it’s out. Doctor: Oh, no. We don’t take everything out. We just take a few things out. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, man, no, we don’t take out anywhere close to your entire blood volume. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just like this much but to do that they have to sort of strain for the right cells. That’s why you’re hooked up to this machine that they have for like two and a half three hours. So, I always say, you know, bring something to read. They play movies. If you have to pee a lot, you bring a urinal so you don’t have to get up because if nurses will start screaming if you move and um there’s two ways. Like you have pretty good veins so um most of the time they can just do it straight from your veins. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They’ll tell us whether that’s possible. A bunch of other people you need a port for six weeks where they actually put it in your arm or your chest and they remove the stuff, you know, out and then when we’re done we pull it out. Now, go like this and you know that your veins are there. They’re not spectacular veins but I don’t think they’re terrible veins. So, it’s like three hours for us to do that procedure and then when you get it reinfused back on a Thursday this stuff comes back in a bag and you get it through Patient: mm hmm.

text: Patient: Yeah, really, yeah. Doctor: You had three others or you know things pop up. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Or the bone disease gets worse—whatever. text: Patient: Oh it’s every three weeks. Doctor: Correct. Patient: So I would take two or three treatments? Doctor: Uh, I’m thinking right now three, three, then we do a repeat scan. And if it’s working, if things are shrinking in there, we keep going. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: On an average people get six. The typical sort of maximum if people are having a tremendous benefit and doing fine with it, you know I can go up to ten. But, but we’ll see how it goes. Patient: Well, I mean (chuckles) Doctor: No, no, I think the hair loss is all pretty much even after one or two, so after we stop the hair grows back. Family Member: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: So, so, that does happen. The other thing to watch for is if there’s tingling or numbness, okay, typically in the fingertips and the toes. If that is happening, I will, you know we may have to make adjustments to the dose. What happens is we start everyone on one standard dose and then dial down, depending on how they’re tolerated. Okay, so, so I think like I told you, the first course pretty much is important because both you and I will find out how you’re going to tolerate. Patient: Right, well my my feet, you know even like right now, they’re a little tingly. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I - you know from sitting in the car for an hour coming up here and that’s -

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
